**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, § 1** and **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred within Worcester County and the damages exceed $50,000.

**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, § 1** and **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred within Worcester County and the damages exceed $50,000.

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.proposition: Under **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973), landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors to avoid foreseeable injuries.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.support_reasoning: Mounsey is the canonical Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a single standard of reasonable care toward all lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage criticizes retaining a separate rule for trespassers, which implicitly acknowledges that the majority opinion extends a reasonable-care duty to all non‑trespassing entrants. Although the excerpt is from a concurrence and focused on trespassers, it is consistent with and presupposes the majority’s holding that occupiers owe reasonable care to all lawful visitors regarding foreseeable injuries.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.proposition: Pursuant to **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368 (2010), Massachusetts landowners owe a duty to remove and treat snow and ice in a reasonable manner and are liable for failing to exercise reasonable care to prevent injuries from accumulations of natural or unnatural snow and ice.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and holds that property owners owe the same duty of reasonable care for snow and ice hazards as for all other hazards. It expressly states that if an owner knows or should know of a dangerous condition from snow or ice, the owner must make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors, thus imposing liability for failing to exercise reasonable care regarding both natural and unnatural accumulations.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards. … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

**Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973,.raw_text: **Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973, Inc.**, 413 Mass. 213 (1992)
**Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable safety measures constitutes negligence under **Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973, Inc.**, 413 Mass. 213 (1992) (landowner liability for failure to remedy known hazards), and **O’Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) (duty to maintain premises in reasonably safe condition).
**Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973,.case_name: Simmons v. Monarch MacHine Tool Co.
**Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973,.support_reasoning: This case is a products-liability / negligent design decision against a manufacturer, not a premises-liability or landowner case. The court discusses a manufacturer's duty to design its product with reasonable care and to guard against reasonably foreseeable risks, including the feasibility of adding a safety shield; it does not address a landowner’s duty to maintain premises or remedy known hazards on land. Thus, citing Jardine here for landowner liability or failure to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition misstates the holding and context of the opinion.
**Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973,.relevant_excerpt: “A manufacturer is under a duty to design its product with reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers… The manufacturer must anticipate the environment in which the product will be used and design against reasonably foreseeable risks attending the product’s use in that setting… In this case, Monarch does not dispute that the bench vise could have been equipped with a shield at minimal cost without interfering with the function of the vise.… [T]he jury reasonably could have concluded that Monarch would have discovered the risk if it had tested its product in the environment in which the product was intended to be used.”

**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable safety measures constitutes negligence under **Jardine v. Upper Darby Lodge No. 1973, Inc.**, 413 Mass. 213 (1992) (landowner liability for failure to remedy known hazards), and **O’Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2000) (duty to maintain premises in reasonably safe condition).
**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The case does restate the general Massachusetts rule that landowners owe a duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. But its holding is that there is no duty where the danger is open and obvious, and it affirms summary judgment for the defendant, finding no negligence for failing to warn or take additional safety measures regarding shallow-end diving. Thus, O’Sullivan limits landowner liability in this context rather than supporting the proposition that failure to take reasonable safety measures here constitutes negligence under Jardine and O’Sullivan.
**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. This duty includes an obligation to ‘maintain[ ] his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances…’ and ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’ … We conclude that… the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries.”

**G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 15\u201317**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated her obligations under **G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–17**, which require reasonable maintenance of ways and sidewalks, and reflects the breach of the common-law duty articulated in **Whittaker v. Saraceno**, 418 Mass. 196 (1994).

**Whittaker v. Saraceno**, 418 Mass. 196.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated her obligations under **G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–17**, which require reasonable maintenance of ways and sidewalks, and reflects the breach of the common-law duty articulated in **Whittaker v. Saraceno**, 418 Mass. 196 (1994).
**Whittaker v. Saraceno**, 418 Mass. 196.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–17, nor any statutory duty to maintain ways or sidewalks; it is a common-law premises liability case about a landlord’s duty to protect lawful entrants from criminal acts of third parties. While it articulates a common-law duty of commercial landowners to take reasonable precautions against reasonably foreseeable criminal acts, the court ultimately finds no duty on these facts and expressly limits that duty to foreseeability. Thus, the case cannot be cited as authority that the defendant’s conduct violated G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–17 or that such statutory obligations were breached in a manner “reflected” in Whittaker’s holding.
**Whittaker v. Saraceno**, 418 Mass. 196.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. … Here the defendant had no duty to the plaintiff to provide protection against a not reasonably foreseeable act of violence against her.”

**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transport.raw_text: **Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority**, 431 Mass. 376 (2000)
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transport.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the hazardous condition through direct communication from her tenants and failed to act reasonably, as recognized in **Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority**, 431 Mass. 376 (2000), and **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transport.case_name: Flemings v. Contributory Retirement Appeal Board
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transport.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns statutory interpretation of veterans’ retirement ‘buy back’ provisions and the definition of ‘veteran’ under Massachusetts retirement law. It does not involve premises liability, landlord‑tenant duties, hazardous conditions, or actual notice from tenants, nor does it discuss any duty to act reasonably in response to such notice. Citing this case for the proposition about a defendant’s actual notice of a hazardous condition is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transport.relevant_excerpt: “The sole issue on appeal is whether, as a matter of law, St. 1996, c. 71, § 2 (act), which amended G. L. c. 32, § 4 (1) (h), to provide certain ‘buy back’ provisions to retirees who have served in the armed forces of the United States or are members of the Massachusetts National Guard or Active Reserve, applies only to individuals who are ‘[v]eteran[s]’ within the definition of G. L. c. 32, § 1, and G. L. c. 4, § 7, Forty-third.”

**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the hazardous condition through direct communication from her tenants and failed to act reasonably, as recognized in **Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority**, 431 Mass. 376 (2000), and **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki does involve a landlord who had actual pre-accident knowledge of a dangerous porch railing and failed to repair it, but the opinion is cited here for a different legal point: abolishing the traditional no-duty rule and imposing a general duty of reasonable care on landlords toward tenants’ guests, including where the defect is on the demised premises. It does not articulate or rely on a rule about the landlord receiving actual notice of a hazardous condition via direct communication from tenants; rather, the landlord’s knowledge came from his insurer. Thus it does not support the specific notice-through-tenant-communication proposition described.
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.relevant_excerpt: “In December, 1976, the landlord’s insurance company had informed him that the railing was dangerous and had cancelled his liability insurance. At that time, the landlord warned the tenant of the danger and bought materials to repair the railing, but he made no repairs. … In particular, a landlord should not be liable in negligence unless he knew or reasonably should have known of the defect and had a reasonable opportunity to repair it.”

**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (20.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act in response to known icy conditions constitutes willful indifference to the safety of others and breaches the standard of reasonable care under **Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (20.support_reasoning: Glidden v. Maglio does not address icy conditions or characterize a failure to act regarding known hazards as willful indifference. The case focuses on lack of proof of causation and absence of evidence that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition, affirming summary judgment for the defendant. It therefore does not support the proposition that a defendant’s failure to act in response to known icy conditions constitutes willful indifference or a breach of reasonable care.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694 (20.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care)."

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and all other available relief under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Award costs, statutory interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**, and any other relief the Court deems just and proper.
